Ok, but we're not building sidewalks...

The power of the Web is in its universality. Access by everyone regardless of disability is an essential aspect.

-Tim Berners-Lee, W3C Director and inventor of the World Wide Web, 1997

Assistive technology

Switch Devices

üôÄ Seems impossible?

Don't panic!

‚å®Ô∏è Keyboard navigation

  • Used across a very wide range devices (e.g. switches, mobile devices)
  • Used by a range of users (vision, mobility, cognitive, power users)

Keyboard cheat sheet

  • Tab - Navigate every interactive element
  • Shift+Tab - Navigate reverse direction
  • Space - Activate form controls
  • ‚Üê / ‚Üí - Move within form control
  • Enter - Visit link or submit form
  • Escape - Close open modal, popover, dropdown

Keyboard functionality checklist

  • You can push the tab key to navigate through every interactive element on the page (links, buttons, form fields, etc.)
  • Every item you navigate to is in a natural reading order matching the visual layout
  • You always can visibly see which element is focused on
  • All form controls can be activated with the space key
  • Links to other pages can be activated with the enter key
  • If there is a modal or popup window open, the keyboard focus always stays inside the modal when pressing tab
  • Important actions are not tedious to focus on

Screen readers üîä

  • Used primarily by people with low vision or blindness
  • Also helps search engines, web scrapers, and other non-visual agents

Voiceover Cheat sheet

  • Command + Fn + F5 : Turn on Voiceover
  • Control + Option + ‚Üê / ‚Üí : Navigate items
  • Control + Option + Space : Click the active item
  • Control : Shut up voice
  • Control + Option + U : Open the rotary menu

Screen reader checklist

  • You should be able to perceive all content on the page, including images, with your eyes closed.
  • Every form element should have an understandable label (and any relevant validation messages should be read out as well)
  • Any notifications (pop-ups, errors, toasts) should speak out loud when they are triggered.
  • BONUS POINTS: Use the rotary menu to browse Landmarks or Headings. These should give a logical overview of the page content.

Exercise: Full Accessibility Audit

How can I use this?

  • Talk with the team and client about your full range of users and the impact of accessibility.
  • Practice keyboard + screen reader tests on your project or on your own time.
  • Quickly test before any new UI gets accepted as complete.
  • Test whenever a full flow is completed
  • Show off your tests during your demo!

Thanks for coming!
